scienceArticles.title: Cannabis Research Highlights – September 2025
scienceArticles.summary: Research published in September 2025 highlights both therapeutic benefits and risks of cannabis use: new pharmacotherapies for cannabis use disorder are being tested; high-THC products are consistently associated with adverse mental health outcomes; preclinical studies confirm anti-inflammatory and antinociceptive effects; and medical cannabis shows improvements in cancer patients’ quality of life, though study quality remains variable.
scienceArticles.content:
# Cannabis Research Highlights – September 2025

Recent cannabis research highlights both therapeutic benefits and risks:
- Novel pharmacotherapies for cannabis use disorder are under review.
- High-THC products are linked to adverse mental health outcomes.
- Preclinical studies confirm anti-inflammatory and antinociceptive effects.
- Medical cannabis may improve quality of life in cancer patients, albeit with methodological limitations.

## Emerging Pharmacological Strategies for Cannabis Use Disorder
**Authors:** Lake et al.  
**Year:** 2025  
**Journal:** Expert Opinion on Emerging Drugs  
**DOI:** 10.1080/14656566.2025.2558999  
**Summary:** Narrative review of pharmacological agents (FAAH inhibitors, orexin antagonists, gabapentin, N-acetylcysteine) for cannabis use disorder. Early-phase data show potential but no drug has robust efficacy for long-term recovery.  
**Limitations:** Small, heterogeneous studies; lack of Phase III trials.

## High-Concentration THC Cannabis Products and Mental Health Outcomes
**Authors:** Gruber et al.  
**Year:** 2025  
**Journal:** Annals of Internal Medicine  
**DOI:** 10.1093/pm/pnaf110  
**Summary:** Systematic review of 99 studies (n=221,097). High-THC products (>10% THC) were linked to higher risks of psychosis, schizophrenia, and cannabis use disorder. Therapeutic effects on anxiety and depression were mixed.  
**Limitations:** Moderate–high bias across studies; inconsistent product definitions.

## Antinociceptive and Anti-inflammatory Effects of Cannabis sativa L.
**Authors:** Martínez-González et al.  
**Year:** 2025  
**Journal:** Frontiers in Pharmacology  
**DOI:** 10.3389/fphar.2025.1677987  
**Summary:** Preclinical rodent study of ethanolic extract of Cannabis sativa reduced writhing, inflammation, and uterine contractions. Active compounds included THC, CBD, CBG, and flavonoids.  
**Limitations:** Animal-only study; translation to humans uncertain.

## Medical Cannabis and Cancer Patients’ Quality of Life
**Authors:** Silva et al.  
**Year:** 2025  
**Journal:** Cannabis and Cannabinoid Research  
**DOI:** 10.1177/27683605251377417  
**Summary:** Review of 16 studies (including 4 RCTs). Medical cannabis improved sleep, appetite, pain, and nausea/vomiting in cancer patients, with mostly mild side effects. Some evidence of improved survival.  
**Limitations:** Small, heterogeneous studies; some potential conflicts of interest.

## Conclusion
Recent evidence shows cannabis has therapeutic promise but also notable risks, particularly with high-THC products. Stronger, large-scale studies are needed to inform balanced regulation in Albania and beyond.
